title: Fourier Series: Wiedijk #76
content:
**Fourier Series** represent periodic functions as sums of sines and cosines:

$$f(x) = \frac{a_0}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left( a_n \cos(nx) + b_n \sin(nx) \right)$$

**Complex form** (more elegant):
$$f(x) = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} c_n e^{inx}$$

**Historical**:
- Fourier (1807) - heat conduction
- Dirichlet (1829) - first rigorous convergence proof
- Carleson (1966) - a.e. convergence for L²

title: Fourier Monomials
content:
**Fourier Monomial eₙ**:
$$e_n(x) = e^{2\pi inx/T}$$

**Properties**:
- $e_n \cdot e_m = e_{n+m}$ (group structure)
- $\overline{e_n} = e_{-n}$ (conjugation)
- These form the basis functions for Fourier expansion

**In Mathlib**: `fourier n` gives the n-th Fourier monomial on `AddCircle T`.

title: Fourier Coefficients
content:
**Fourier Coefficient cₙ(f)**:
$$c_n = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} f(x) e^{-inx} dx$$

**Relation to real coefficients**:
- $c_0 = a_0/2$
- $c_n = (a_n - ib_n)/2$ for n > 0
- $c_{-n} = \overline{c_n}$ for real f

**Key insight**: Inner product projection onto basis element eₙ.

title: Orthonormality of Fourier System
content:
**Orthonormality** (Key Lemma):

$$\langle e_n, e_m \rangle = \delta_{nm} = \begin{cases} 1 & n = m \\ 0 & n \neq m \end{cases}$$

**Classical form**:
- $\int \sin(nx)\cos(mx)dx = 0$ (always)
- $\int \sin(nx)\sin(mx)dx = 0$ when $n \neq m$
- $\int \cos(nx)\cos(mx)dx = 0$ when $n \neq m$

**Why it matters**: Orthogonality makes coefficient extraction via projection work!

title: Hilbert Basis (Completeness)
content:
**Completeness Theorem**:

The Fourier monomials {eₙ}_{n∈ℤ} form a **Hilbert basis** for L².

**Equivalent statements**:
1. span{eₙ} is dense in L²
2. Parseval's identity holds: ‖f‖² = Σ|cₙ|²
3. No nonzero f is orthogonal to all eₙ

**Consequence**: Every L² function has a unique Fourier series representation.

title: L² Convergence
content:
**L² Convergence Theorem**:

For any f ∈ L², the Fourier series converges in L² norm:
$$f = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} c_n e_n \quad \text{(L² sense)}$$

**What this means**:
$$\left\| f - \sum_{|n| \leq N} c_n e_n \right\|_{L^2} \to 0 \text{ as } N \to \infty$$

**Note**: L² convergence ≠ pointwise convergence. But Carleson proved a.e. pointwise convergence for L².

title: Parseval's Theorem
content:
**Parseval's Theorem** (Energy Equality):

$$\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} |c_n|^2 = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} |f(x)|^2 dx = \|f\|_{L^2}^2$$

**Physical interpretation**:
- LHS: Total power in frequency domain
- RHS: Total power in time domain
- **Energy is conserved!**

Also called **Plancherel theorem** for Fourier series.

title: Bessel's Inequality
content:
**Bessel's Inequality**:

For any orthonormal system and any f:
$$\sum_{n} |\langle f, e_n \rangle|^2 \leq \|f\|^2$$

**Key points**:
- Holds for any orthonormal system
- Equality iff system is complete (Parseval)
- Useful for bounding partial sums

**Fourier case**: Since {eₙ} is complete, Bessel becomes Parseval.

title: Uniform Convergence
content:
**Uniform Convergence Theorem**:

If Σ|cₙ| < ∞ (absolutely summable coefficients), then the Fourier series converges **uniformly** to f.

**When does this hold?**
- Smooth functions (C¹ or better)
- Integration by parts gives cₙ = O(1/n²)

**Hierarchy**:
Uniform convergence ⟹ pointwise ⟹ L² convergence

title: Uniqueness of Fourier Series
content:
**Uniqueness Theorem**:

If two L² functions have identical Fourier coefficients, they are equal (a.e.).

$$\forall n: c_n(f) = c_n(g) \Rightarrow f = g$$

**Proof**: Follows from completeness of Fourier basis.

**Important**: The Fourier series representation is **unique**.

title: Riemann-Lebesgue Lemma
content:
**Riemann-Lebesgue Lemma**:

Fourier coefficients of L² functions decay to zero:
$$\lim_{|n| \to \infty} c_n(f) = 0$$

**Proof idea**: Since Σ|cₙ|² < ∞ (Parseval), we must have cₙ → 0.

**Consequence**: High-frequency components contribute less energy. This is why Fourier series approximate functions well with finite terms.
